This is a design bugreport originated from the discussion in #6064.
I'll quote the description from ``qx.bom``:
*Low-level Browser Object Model layer. This is a low-level layer providing a cross-browser abstraction for object classes typically found in the browser JavaScript runtime.*
Currently there're classes that don't comply with package definition.
``qx.bom.request.Jsonp``. *JSONP* is a *SOP* circumvent, so it's orthogonal to a browser object model. It's a io-level abstraction. Because it serves a purpose of lower layer for end-user ``qx.io.request.Jsonp``, it should probably be placed under ``qx.io.request`` as internal class.
``qx.bom.rest``. *REST* is just a convention of *HTTP* method usage. Again, it has nothing to do with browser object model. It's a io-level abstraction. As the only class in the package, ``qx.bom.rest.Resource``, is a lower layer for ``qx.io.rest.Resource``, it should probably be placed under ``qx.io.rest`` as internal class.
``qx.bom.request.SimpleXhr``. Considering its description *this class is internal because it's tailored to qx.io.rest.Resource which needs more functionality than qx.bom.request.Xhr provides* the name is misguiding as it's more a *SpecialXhr*. If its purpose is solely an another low-level class for ``qx.io.rest.Resource``, then it should probably be placed under ``qx.io.rest`` as internal class.
